etymology.description: 波(boobs in Cantonese slang, from ‘ball/wave’) + 霸(overlord; top dog) = extremely busty woman.
etymology.interpretation: Cantonese slang where 波 refers to breasts and 霸 means an overlord, so it labels a woman with very large breasts. Later in Taiwan it was repurposed to name large tapioca pearls (“boba”).

examples.chinese: 她是个波霸(她是個波霸)。
这个词很口语(這個詞很口語)，有时被认为物化女性(有時被認為物化女性)。
examples.pinyin: Zhège cí hěn kǒuyǔ, yǒushí bèi rènwéi wùhuà nǚxìng.
examples.english: This term is very colloquial and is sometimes considered objectifying.

examples.chinese: 在台湾，“波霸”也用来指大颗珍珠奶茶的珍珠(在臺灣，「波霸」也用來指大顆珍珠奶茶的珍珠)。
examples.pinyin: Zài Táiwān, “bōbà” yě yònglái zhǐ dà kē zhēnzhū nǎichá de zhēnzhū.
examples.english: In Taiwan, “boba” is also used for the large tapioca pearls in milk tea.
